revision.comment: Added date-stamp info here for other Wikipedians as the information is hard to find.
revision.text:
'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
For Wikipedia users, to automatically sign posts with a date-stamp, add four tildes (<nowiki>~~~~</nowiki>) at the end of your message; or add three tildes (<nowiki>~~~</nowiki>) to add ''just'' your name.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161: Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]]

'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix Time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.

revision.comment: Added diagram and text on trusted timestamping
revision.text:
'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
== Trusted Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|300px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party]] A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a timestamping authority (TSA). It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps.
The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This last hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data. Note that since that the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161: Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]]

'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
== Trusted Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a timestamping authority (TSA). It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps.
The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This last hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data. Note that since that the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data. [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] == External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161: Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]]

'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
== Trusted Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps.
The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This last hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data. Note that since that the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data. [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] == External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161: Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]]

'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
== Trusted Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. ====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] It can now no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161: Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]]

__NOTOC__ '''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
== Trusted Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. ====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] It can now no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161: Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]]

To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA. what's up.

Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
== Trusted Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. ====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] It can now no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161 Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)] *[http://www.itconsult.co.uk/stamper.htm Free timestamp service]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Sellado_de_tiempo]]

Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161 Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)] *[http://www.itconsult.co.uk/stamper.htm Free timestamp service]

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ :''For the ICMP message, see [[ICMP Timestamp]]''.
'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
== Trusted Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] It can now no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161 Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)] *[http://www.itconsult.co.uk/stamper.htm Free timestamp service]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Sellado_de_tiempo]]

revision.comment: /* Trusted Timestamping */ Merged in the article "digital timestamping"
revision.text:
__NOTOC__ :''For the ICMP message, see [[ICMP Timestamp]]''.
'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
== Trusted (Digital) Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] '''Trusted timestamping''' is the process of [[computer security|securely]] keeping track of the creation and modification time of a document. Security here means that no one—not even the owner of the document—should be able to change it once it has been recorded provided that the timestamper's integrity is never compromised. The administrative aspect involves setting up a publicly available, trusted timestamp management infrastructure to collect, process and renew timestamps.
A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161 Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)] *[http://www.itconsult.co.uk/stamper.htm Free timestamp service (UK based)] *[http://www.signedtimestamp.org/ Free timestamp service (Netherlands based)]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Sellado_de_tiempo]]

revision.comment: Merged history section and external links of "digital timestamping article into this page
revision.text:
__NOTOC__ :''For the ICMP message, see [[ICMP Timestamp]]''.
'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
==History== The idea of timestamping information is actually centuries old. For example, when [[Robert Hooke]] discovered [[Hooke's law]] in [[1660]], he did not want to publish it yet, but wanted to be able to claim priority. So he published the [[anagram]] ''ceiiinosssttuv'' and later published the translation ''ut tensio sic vis''. Similarly, [[Galileo Galilei|Galileo]] first published his discovery of the phases of Venus in the anagram form. A modern example is the case of an industrial research organization that may later need to prove, for patent purposes, that they made a particular discovery on a particular date; since magnetic media can be altered easily, this may be a nontrivial issue. One possible solution is for a researcher to compute and record in a hardcopy laboratory notebook a cryptographic hash of the relevant data file. In the future, should there be a need to prove the version of this file retrieved from a backup tape has not been altered, the hash function could be recomputed and compared with the hash value recorded in that paper notebook.
== Trusted (Digital) Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] '''Trusted timestamping''' is the process of [[computer security|securely]] keeping track of the creation and modification time of a document. Security here means that no one—not even the owner of the document—should be able to change it once it has been recorded provided that the timestamper's integrity is never compromised. The administrative aspect involves setting up a publicly available, trusted timestamp management infrastructure to collect, process and renew timestamps.
A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is send back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.
== External links == *[http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt RFC3161 Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP)] *[http://www.itconsult.co.uk/stamper.htm Free timestamp service (UK based)] *[http://www.signedtimestamp.org/ Free timestamp service (Netherlands based)] * [http://www.rsasecurity.com/rsalabs/node.asp?id=2347 RSA Laboratories - What is digital timestamping?] * [http://citeseer.csail.mit.edu/haber91how.html How to Time-stamp a Digital Document] (1991) Stuart Haber, W. Scott Stornetta, Lecture Notes in Computer Science
==See also== * [[Cryptography]] * [[Computer security]] * [[Digital signature]]
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Sellado_de_tiempo]]

One possible solution is for a researcher to compute and record in a hardcopy laboratory notebook a cryptographic hash of the relevant data file. == Trusted (Digital) Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] '''Trusted timestamping''' is the process of [[computer security|securely]] keeping track of the creation and modification time of a document. Security here means that no one—not even the owner of the document—should be able to change it once it has been recorded provided that the timestamper's integrity is never compromised. The administrative aspect involves setting up a publicly available, trusted timestamp management infrastructure to collect, process and renew timestamps.
A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is sent back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.

It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is sent back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.

'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
==History== The idea of timestamping information is actually centuries old. For example, when [[Robert Hooke]] discovered [[Hooke's law]] in [[1660]], he did not want to publish it yet, but wanted to be able to claim priority. So he published the [[anagram]] ''ceiiinosssttuv'' and later published the translation ''ut tensio sic vis'' (Latin for "as is the extension, so is the force"). Similarly, [[Galileo Galilei|Galileo]] first published his discovery of the phases of Venus in the anagram form. A modern example is the case of an industrial research organization that may later need to prove, for patent purposes, that they made a particular discovery on a particular date; since magnetic media can be altered easily, this may be a nontrivial issue. One possible solution is for a researcher to compute and record in a hardcopy laboratory notebook a cryptographic hash of the relevant data file. In the future, should there be a need to prove the version of this file retrieved from a backup tape has not been altered, the hash function could be recomputed and compared with the hash value recorded in that paper notebook.

Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.

To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.

====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is sent back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
Simple solution used in previous times was to post sensitive data via official state post service to your own address, since post stamp is an official time-stamp recognized in court.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.

Scott Stornetta, Lecture Notes in Computer Science

:''For the ICMP message, see [[ICMP Timestamp]]''.
'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digital signature|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
==History== The idea of timestamping information is actually centuries old. For example, when [[Robert Hooke]] discovered [[Hooke's law]] in [[1660]], he did not want to publish it yet, but wanted to be able to claim priority. So he published the [[anagram]] ''ceiiinosssttuv'' and later published the translation ''ut tensio sic vis'' (Latin for "as is the extension, so is the force"). Similarly, [[Galileo Galilei|Galileo]] first published his discovery of the phases of Venus in the anagram form. A modern example is the case of an industrial research organization that may later need to prove, for patent purposes, that they made a particular discovery on a particular date; since magnetic media can be altered easily, this may be a nontrivial issue. One possible solution is for a researcher to compute and record in a hardcopy laboratory notebook a cryptographic hash of the relevant data file. In the future, should there be a need to prove the version of this file retrieved from a backup tape has not been altered, the hash function could be recomputed and compared with the hash value recorded in that paper notebook.
== Trusted (Digital) Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] '''Trusted timestamping''' is the process of [[computer security|securely]] keeping track of the creation and modification time of a document. Security here means that no one—not even the owner of the document—should be able to change it once it has been recorded provided that the timestamper's integrity is never compromised. The administrative aspect involves setting up a publicly available, trusted timestamp management infrastructure to collect, process and renew timestamps.
A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is sent back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
Simple solution used in previous times was to post sensitive data via official state post service to your own address, since post stamp is an official time-stamp recognized in court.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.
== External links == *RFC 3161 Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Time-Stamp Protocol (TSP) *[http://www.itconsult.co.uk/stamper.htm Free timestamp service (UK based)] *[http://www.signedtimestamp.org/ Free timestamp service (Netherlands based)] * [http://www.rsasecurity.com/rsalabs/node.asp?id=2347 RSA Laboratories - What is digital timestamping?] * [http://citeseer.csail.mit.edu/haber91how.html How to Time-stamp a Digital Document] (1991) Stuart Haber, W. == Trusted (Digital) Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] '''Trusted timestamping''' is the process of [[computer security|securely]] keeping track of the creation and modification time of a document. Security here means that no one—not even the owner of the document—should be able to change it once it has been recorded provided that the timestamper's integrity is never compromised. The administrative aspect involves setting up a publicly available, trusted timestamp management infrastructure to collect, process and renew timestamps.
A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is sent back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
Simple solution used in previous times was to post sensitive data via official state post service to your own address, since post stamp is an official time-stamp recognized in court.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.

:''For the ICMP message, see [[ICMP Timestamp]]''.

Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.

For example, when [[Robert Hooke]] discovered [[Hooke's law]] in [[1660]], he did not want to publish it yet, but wanted to be able to claim priority. A modern example is the case of an industrial research organization that may later need to prove, for patent purposes, that they made a particular discovery on a particular date; since magnetic media can be altered easily, this may be a nontrivial issue. One possible solution is for a researcher to compute and record in a hardcopy laboratory notebook a cryptographic hash of the relevant data file. In the future, should there be a need to prove the version of this file retrieved from a backup tape has not been altered, the hash function could be recomputed and compared with the hash value recorded in that paper notebook.
== Trusted (Digital) Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] '''Trusted timestamping''' is the process of [[computer security|securely]] keeping track of the creation and modification time of a document. The administrative aspect involves setting up a publicly available, trusted timestamp management infrastructure to collect, process and renew timestamps.

It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.

To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.

[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Sellado de tiempo]] [[fr:Timestamp]]

:''For the ICMP message, see [[ICMP Timestamp]]''.
'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digitally signed]] timestamp whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.
Timestamps are very useful for [[Data logging|logging]] events.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
==History== The idea of timestamping information is actually centuries old. For example, when [[Robert Hooke]] discovered [[Hooke's law]] in [[1660]], he did not want to publish it yet, but wanted to be able to claim priority. So he published the [[anagram]] ''ceiiinosssttuv'' and later published the translation ''ut tensio sic vis'' (Latin for "as is the extension, so is the force"). Similarly, [[Galileo Galilei|Galileo]] first published his discovery of the phases of Venus in the anagram form. A modern example is the case of an industrial research organization that may later need to prove, for patent purposes, that they made a particular discovery on a particular date; since magnetic media can be altered easily, this may be a nontrivial issue. One possible solution is for a researcher to compute and record in a hardcopy laboratory notebook a cryptographic hash of the relevant data file. In the future, should there be a need to prove the version of this file retrieved from a backup tape has not been altered, the hash function could be recomputed and compared with the hash value recorded in that paper notebook.
== Trusted (Digital) Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] '''Trusted timestamping''' is the process of [[computer security|securely]] keeping track of the creation and modification time of a document. Security here means that no one—not even the owner of the document—should be able to change it once it has been recorded provided that the timestamper's integrity is never compromised. The administrative aspect involves setting up a publicly available, trusted timestamp management infrastructure to collect, process and renew timestamps.
A trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is sent back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
Simple solution used in previous times was to post sensitive data via official state post service to your own address, since post stamp is an official time-stamp recognized in court.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.

:''For the ICMP message, see [[ICMP Timestamp]]''.
'''Timestamp''' can refer to a [[time code]] or to a [[digitally signed]] timestamp whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature.

'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
Many sources also use the term '''timestamp''' to refer specifically to [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970.
==History== The idea of timestamping information is actually centuries old. For example, when [[Robert Hooke]] discovered [[Hooke's law]] in [[1660]], he did not want to publish it yet, but wanted to be able to claim priority. So he published the [[anagram]] ''ceiiinosssttuv'' and later published the translation ''ut tensio sic vis'' (Latin for "as is the extension, so is the force"). Similarly, [[Galileo Galilei|Galileo]] first published his discovery of the phases of Venus in the anagram form. A modern example is the case of an industrial research organization that may later need to prove, for patent purposes, that they made a particular discovery on a particular date; since magnetic media can be altered easily, this may be a nontrivial issue. == Trusted (Digital) Timestamping == [[Image:Trusted timestamping.gif|thumb|right|350px|Getting a timestamp from a trusted third party.]] '''Trusted timestamping''' is the process of [[computer security|securely]] keeping track of the creation and modification time of a document. Security here means that no one—not even the owner of the document—should be able to change it once it has been recorded provided that the timestamper's integrity is never compromised. The administrative aspect involves setting up a publicly available, trusted timestamp management infrastructure to collect, process and renew timestamps.
According to the [http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3161 RFC 3161 standard], a trusted timestamp is a timestamp issued by a trusted third party (TTP) acting as a '''timestamping authority (TSA)'''. It is used to prove the existence of certain data before a certain point (e.g. contracts, research data, medical records,...) without the possibility that the owner can backdate the timestamps. Multiple TSAs can be used to increase reliability and reduce vulnerability.
The newer [[ANSI ASC X9.95 Standard | ANSI_ASC_X9.95_Standard]] for [[Timestamp |trusted timestamps]] augments the RFC 3161 standard with data-level security requirements to ensure [[Data integrity | data integrity]] against a reliable time source that is provable to any third party. This standard has been applied to authenticating digitally signed data for regulatory compliance, financial transactions, and legal evidence. For example, the X9.95 standard has been implemented by [http://www.proofspace.com ProofSpace, Inc.] in its [[Transient-key cryptography | transient key]] technology to address emerging requirements to prove data integrity across the entire [[Chain of custody | custody chain]] of any document or record for admission as evidence in a court of law.
====Creating a timestamp==== The technique is based on [[digital signatures]] and [[hash functions]]. First a hash is calculated from the data. A hash is a sort of digital fingerprint of the original data: a string of bits that is different for each set of data. If the original data is changed then this will result in a completely different hash. This hash is sent to the TSA. The TSA concatenates a timestamp to the hash and calculates the hash of this concatenation. This hash is in turn [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the [[private key]] of the TSA. This signed hash + the timestamp is sent back to the requester of the timestamp who stores these with the original data (see diagram).
Since the original data can not be calculated from the hash (because the [[hash function]] is a [[one way function]]), the TSA never gets to see the original data, which allows the use of this method for confidential data.
Simple solution used in previous times was to post sensitive data via official state post service to your own address, since post stamp is an official time-stamp recognized in court.
====Checking the timestamp==== [[Image:Checking timestamp.gif|thumb|right|350px|Checking correctness of a timestamp generated by a time stamping authority (TSA).]] Anyone trusting the timestamper can then verify that the document was ''not'' created ''after'' the date that the timestamper vouches. It can also no longer be repudiated that the requester of the timestamp was in possession of the original data at the time given by the timestamp. To prove this (see diagram) the [[hash]] of the original data is calculated, the timestamp given by the TSA is appended to it and the hash of the result of this concatenation is calculated, call this hash A.
Then the [[digital signature]] of the TSA is to be checked by decrypting the signed hash given by the TSA with the [[public key]] of the TSA. This results in the decrypted hash, let us call this hash B. If hash A equals hash B then the timestamp is unaltered and was issued by the TSA. If not, then either the timestamp was altered or the timestamp was not issued by the TSA.

[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Sellado de tiempo]] [[fr:Timestamp]]

'''Timestamp''' is a sequence of characters, denoting the date and/or time at which a certain event occured.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging]] events, in which case each event in a log is marked with a timestamp.
'''Examples''' 2005-10-30 10:45 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
In Wikipedia, timestamp means the date/time used in a [[Wikipedia:Signatures|user signature]], showing who and when have made a certain comment.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature
{{disambig}}
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Sellado de tiempo]] [[fr:Timestamp]]

'''Timestamp''' is a sequence of characters, denoting the date and/or time at which a certain event occured. This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]], in which case each event in a log is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
Examples of timestamps: 2005-10-30 10:45 2007-11-09 11:20 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
In Wikipedia, a timestamp is the date/time used in a [[Wikipedia:Signatures|user signature]], showing who and when have made a certain comment.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer vouches for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the digital signature
{{disambig}}
[[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Sellado de tiempo]] [[fr:Timestamp]]

'''Timestamp''' is a sequence of characters, denoting the date and/or time at which a certain event occured. This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]], in which case each event in a log is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
Examples of timestamps: 2005-10-30 10:45 2007-11-09 11:20 Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=June 2008}} A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters, denoting the date and/or time at which a certain event occurred. This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]], in which case each event in a log is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
Examples of timestamps: 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005
==Standardization== The [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO) has defined [[ISO 8601]] which standardizes timestamps.
==Other meanings== {{wiktionary}}
'''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]]
{{disambig}} [[Category:Time]]
[[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Timestamp]] [[fr:Timestamp]] [[it:Marca temporale]] [[lv:Laika zīmogs]] [[ru:Timestamp]]

Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]], in which case each event in a log is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2008}} A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters, denoting the date and/or time at which a certain event occurred. A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be very, very close to the time of the occurrence of the event recorded.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]], in which case each event in a log is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
Examples of timestamps: 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 1256953732
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times. These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== {{wiktionary}}
'''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]]
[[Category:Time]]

==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.

==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== {{wiktionary}}
'''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]], in which case each event in a log is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples ==
Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *1256953732
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{wiktionary}}
[[Category:Time]]
[[ar:ختم زمني]] [[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Timestamp]] [[fr:Horodatage]] [[ko:타임스탬프]] [[it:Marca temporale]] [[he:חותם זמן]] [[pt:Marca temporal]] [[ru:Timestamp]] [[zh:時間戳記]]

{{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters, denoting the date and/or time at which a certain event occurred. A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be very, very close to the time of the occurrence of the event recorded.
In some cases, a timestamp can be just the numbering of events, the use of a date_time format to store a timestamp is then not mandatory.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]], in which case each event in a log is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *1256953732 *(1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC)-1st FootStep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind"
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{wiktionary}}
[[Category:Time]]

{{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} [[File:Autographic Kodak writing.jpg|thumb|In 1915, timestamping was less automatic.]] [[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A physical time stamp on a letter, showing the date (in the center) and time the letter was received]]
A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters, denoting the date or time at which a certain event occurred. A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be very, very close to the time of the occurrence of the event recorded.
In some cases, a timestamp can be just the numbering of events, the use of a date_time format to store a timestamp is then not mandatory.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *1256953732 *(1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC)-1st FootStep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind"
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]]
==See also== * [[Trusted timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{wiktionary}}
[[Category:Time]]
[[ar:ختم زمني]] [[de:Zeitstempel]] [[es:Timestamp]] [[fr:Horodatage]] [[ko:타임스탬프]] [[it:Marca temporale]] [[he:חותם זמן]] [[hu:Időbélyegző]] [[ja:タイムスタンプ]] [[pt:Marca temporal]] [[ru:Timestamp]] [[zh:時間戳記]]

{{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} [[File:Autographic Kodak writing.jpg|thumb|In 1915, timestamping was less automatic.]] [[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A physical time stamp on a letter, showing the date (in the center) and time the letter was received]]

* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]]
