A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters, denoting the date or time at which a certain event occurred. The term refers to [[rubber stamp]]s that are used in offices to stamp the current date and time in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. However, in modern times its usage has expanded to refer to data stored in a computer or digital electronic equipment. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was created and last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be very, very close to the time of the occurrence of the event recorded.
In some cases, a timestamp can be just the numbering of events, the use of a date_time format to store a timestamp is then not mandatory.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *1256953732 *(1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC)-1st FootStep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind"
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== * [[Trusted timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{wiktionary}}
[[Category:Time]]

==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be very, very close to the time of the occurrence of the event recorded.
In some cases, a timestamp can be just the numbering of events, the use of a date_time format to store a timestamp is then not mandatory.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *1256953732 *(1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC) -- 1st Footstep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind"
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== * [[Trusted timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{wiktionary}}

Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *1256953732 *(1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC) -- 1st Footstep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind"
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{wiktionary}}

A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. A common example of this type of timestamp is a [[postmark]] on a letter. However, in modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.

==See also== {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *1256953732 *(1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC) -- 1st Footstep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind" *07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} {{quality|date=April 2012}} [[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]] [[File:Zeitstempel 01.jpg|thumb|German date and time stamp, a rubber stamp that stamps the current date and time on a document, 1960s]] [[File:Autographic Kodak writing.jpg|thumb|Advertisement for a 1915 camera, that stamped the time each picture was taken in ink on the picture. ]]
A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. A common example of this type of timestamp is a [[postmark]] on a letter. However, in modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *12569537329 *(1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC) -- 1st Footstep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind" *07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]

* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} {{quality|date=April 2012}} }}
[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]] [[File:Zeitstempel 01.jpg|thumb|German date and time stamp, a rubber stamp that stamps the current date and time on a document, 1960s]] [[File:Autographic Kodak writing.jpg|thumb|Advertisement for a 1915 camera, that stamped the time each picture was taken in ink on the film. ]]
A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received.
Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]]. However, in modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: *2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] *2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] *Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 *12569537329 *(1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC) -- 1st Footstep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind" *07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it proves the image isn't a download) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} {{quality|date=April 2012}} }}
[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]] [[File:Zeitstempel 01.jpg|thumb|German date and time stamp, a rubber stamp that stamps the current date and time on a [[document]], 1960s]] [[File:Autographic Kodak writing.jpg|thumb|Advertisement for a 1915 camera, that stamped the time each picture was taken in ink on the film. ]]
A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received.
Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]]. However, in modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Tue 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 12569537329 * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} first footstep on the Moon, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind" * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]] [[File:Zeitstempel 01.jpg|thumb|German date and time stamp, a rubber stamp that stamps the current date and time on a [[document]], 1960s]] [[File:Autographic Kodak writing.jpg|thumb|Advertisement for a 1915 Kodak [[Autographic film|Autographic]] camera, which enabled the photographer to write information on the film such as the date a photo was taken.]]

[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]] [[File:Zeitstempel 01.jpg|thumb|German date and time stamp, a rubber stamp that stamps the current date and time on a [[document]], 1960s]] [[File:Autographic Kodak writing.jpg|thumb|Advertisement for a 1915 Kodak [[Autographic film|Autographic]] camera. A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]].
In modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}.
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Tue 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 12569537329 * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} first footstep on the Moon, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind" * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Linked timestamping]]

==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted_timestamping#Decentralized_timestamping_on_the_Blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the Blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]] [[File:Zeitstempel 01.jpg|thumb|German date and time stamp, a rubber stamp that stamps the current date and time on a [[document]], 1960s]] [[File:Autographic Kodak writing.jpg|thumb|Advertisement for a 1915 Kodak [[Autographic film|Autographic]] camera. The picture shows a photographer writing directly onto the film inside the camera. He may have been recording the date of the photograph that he had just taken.]]
A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]].
In modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself<ref name="BernsteinNewcomer2009">{{cite book|author1=Philip A. Bernstein|author2=Eric Newcomer|title=Principles of Transaction Processing|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=LmHgK5KKrQQC&pg=PA263|date=24 July 2009|publisher=Morgan Kaufmann|isbn=978-0-08-094841-6|page=263}}</ref>. In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping<ref name="Medeiros2009">{{cite book|author=Claudia Maria Bauzer Medeiros|title=ADVANCED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS -Volume I|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=kBnFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=19 September 2009|publisher=EOLSS Publications|isbn=978-1-905839-91-9|pages=59}}</ref>
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Tue 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]]) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} first footstep on the Moon, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind" * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted_timestamping#Decentralized_timestamping_on_the_Blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the Blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the Blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the Blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]

This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.

* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the Blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the Blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]][[ISO 8601|is]] a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]].
In modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself.<ref name="BernsteinNewcomer2009">{{cite book|author1=Philip A. Bernstein|author2=Eric Newcomer|title=Principles of Transaction Processing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LmHgK5KKrQQC&pg=PA263|date=24 July 2009|publisher=Morgan Kaufmann|isbn=978-0-08-094841-6|page=263}}</ref> In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping.<ref name="Medeiros2009">{{cite book|author=Claudia Maria Bauzer Medeiros|title=ADVANCED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS -Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBnFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=19 September 2009|publisher=EOLSS Publications|isbn=978-1-905839-91-9|pages=59}}</ref>
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Tue 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]]) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC) * 1985-102 T 10:15 UTC ''(day 102 of year 1985 = 12 April 1985)'' * 1985-W15-5 T 10:15 UTC ''(day 5 of week 15 of year 1985 = 12 April 1985)''
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the Blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the Blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself.<ref name="BernsteinNewcomer2009">{{cite book|author1=Philip A. Bernstein|author2=Eric Newcomer|title=Principles of Transaction Processing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LmHgK5KKrQQC&pg=PA263|date=24 July 2009|publisher=Morgan Kaufmann|isbn=978-0-08-094841-6|page=263}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=March 2018}} In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called '''timestamping'''. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping.<ref name="Medeiros2009">{{cite book|author=Claudia Maria Bauzer Medeiros|title=ADVANCED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS -Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBnFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=19 September 2009|publisher=EOLSS Publications|isbn=978-1-905839-91-9|pages=59}}</ref>
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. In filesystems, timestamp may mean the stored date/time of creation or modification of a file.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Tue 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]]) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC) * 1985-102 T 10:15 UTC ''(day 102 of year 1985 = 12 April 1985)'' * 1985-W15-5 T 10:15 UTC ''(day 5 of week 15 of year 1985 = 12 April 1985)'' * 20180203073000 (02/03/2018 7:30:00)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

revision.text:
[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]]
A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]].
In modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself.<ref name="BernsteinNewcomer2009">{{cite book|author1=Philip A. Bernstein|author2=Eric Newcomer|title=Principles of Transaction Processing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LmHgK5KKrQQC&pg=PA263|date=24 July 2009|publisher=Morgan Kaufmann|isbn=978-0-08-094841-6|page=263}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=March 2018}} In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called [[timestamping (computing) | '''timestamping''']]. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping.<ref name="Medeiros2009">{{cite book|author=Claudia Maria Bauzer Medeiros|title=ADVANCED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS -Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBnFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=19 September 2009|publisher=EOLSS Publications|isbn=978-1-905839-91-9|pages=59}}</ref>
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp.
Practically all computer file systems store one or more timestamps in the [[file system#Metadata | per-file metadata]]. In particular, most modern operating systems support the POSIX [[stat (system call)]], so each file has 3 timestamps associated with it: time of last access (atime: ls -lu), time of last modification (mtime: ls -l), and time of last status change (ctime: ls -lc).
Some [[file archiver]]s and some [[comparison of version control software | version control software]], when they copy a file from some remote computer to the local computer, "fix" the timestamps of the local file to show the date/time in the past when that file was created or modified on that remote computer, rather than the date/time when that file was copied to the local computer.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Tue 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]]) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC) * 1985-102 T 10:15 UTC ''(day 102 of year 1985 = 12 April 1985)'' * 1985-W15-5 T 10:15 UTC ''(day 5 of week 15 of year 1985 = 12 April 1985)'' * 20180203073000 (02/03/2018 7:30:00)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]]
A '''timestampS''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]].
In modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself.<ref name="BernsteinNewcomer2009">{{cite book|author1=Philip A. Bernstein|author2=Eric Newcomer|title=Principles of Transaction Processing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LmHgK5KKrQQC&pg=PA263|date=24 July 2009|publisher=Morgan Kaufmann|isbn=978-0-08-094841-6|page=263}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=March 2018}} In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called [[timestamping (computing) | '''timestamping''']]. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping.<ref name="Medeiros2009">{{cite book|author=Claudia Maria Bauzer Medeiros|title=ADVANCED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS -Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBnFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=19 September 2009|publisher=EOLSS Publications|isbn=978-1-905839-91-9|pages=59}}</ref>
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp.
Practically all computer file systems store one or more timestamps in the [[file system#Metadata | per-file metadata]]. In particular, most modern operating systems support the POSIX [[stat (system call)]], so each file has 3 timestamps associated with it: time of last access (atime: ls -lu), time of last modification (mtime: ls -l), and time of last status change (ctime: ls -lc).
Some [[file archiver]]s and some [[comparison of version control software | version control software]], when they copy a file from some remote computer to the local computer, adjust the timestamps of the local file to show the date/time in the past when that file was created or modified on that remote computer, rather than the date/time when that file was copied to the local computer.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Tue 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]]) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC) * 1985-102 T 10:15 UTC ''(day 102 of year 1985 = 12 April 1985)'' * 1985-W15-5 T 10:15 UTC ''(day 5 of week 15 of year 1985 = 12 April 1985)'' * 20180203073000 (02/03/2018 7:30:00)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]

In particular, most modern operating systems support the POSIX [[stat (system call)]], so each file has 3 timestamps associated with it: time of last access (atime: ls -lu), time of last modification (mtime: ls -l), and time of last status change (ctime: ls -lc).
Some [[file archiver]]s and some [[comparison of version control software | version control software]], when they copy a file from some remote computer to the local computer, adjust the timestamps of the local file to show the date/time in the past when that file was created or modified on that remote computer, rather than the date/time when that file was copied to the local computer.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Wed 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]]) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC) * 1985-102 T 10:15 UTC ''(year 1985, day 102 = 12 April 1985)'' * 1985-W15-5 T 10:15 UTC ''(year 1985, week 15, day 5 = 12 April 1985)'' * 20180203073000 (02/03/2018 7:30:00)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

[[File:Timestamp.png|thumb|A [[postmark]] on a letter, with a timestamp showing the date ''(center)'' and time the letter was received by the post office.]]
A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]].
In modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.
==Digital timestamps== A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself.<ref name="BernsteinNewcomer2009">{{cite book|author1=Philip A. Bernstein|author2=Eric Newcomer|title=Principles of Transaction Processing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LmHgK5KKrQQC&pg=PA263|date=24 July 2009|publisher=Morgan Kaufmann|isbn=978-0-08-094841-6|page=263}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=March 2018}} In many cases, the difference may be inconsequential: the time at which an event is recorded by a timestamp (e.g., entered into a log file) should be close to the time of the event.
This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called [[timestamping (computing) | '''timestamping''']]. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping.<ref name="Medeiros2009">{{cite book|author=Claudia Maria Bauzer Medeiros|title=ADVANCED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS -Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBnFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=19 September 2009|publisher=EOLSS Publications|isbn=978-1-905839-91-9|pages=59}}</ref>
Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp.
Practically all computer file systems store one or more timestamps in the [[file system#Metadata | per-file metadata]]. In particular, most modern operating systems support the POSIX [[stat (system call)]], so each file has 3 timestamps associated with it: time of last access (atime: ls -lu), time of last modification (mtime: ls -l), and time of last status change (ctime: ls -lc).
Some [[file archiver]]s and some [[comparison of version control software | version control software]], when they copy a file from some remote computer to the local computer, adjust the timestamps of the local file to show the date/time in the past when that file was created or modified on that remote computer, rather than the date/time when that file was copied to the local computer.
== Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Wed 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]]) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC) * 1985-102 T 10:15 UTC ''(year 1985, day 102 = 12 April 1985)'' * 1985-W15-5 T 10:15 UTC ''(year 1985, week 15, day 5 = 12 April 1985)'' * 20180203073000 (02/03/2018 7:30:00)
==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}}</ref> These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values.
==Other meanings== '''Timestamp''' can also refer to:
* A [[time code]] (in networking or video technology) * [[Unix time]], the number of seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on January 1, 1970 * [[ICMP Timestamp]] * A [[Trusted timestamping|digitally signed timestamp]] whose signer [[wikt:vouch|vouches]] for the existence of the signed document or content at the time given as part of the [[digital signature]] * The modification or access [[system time|time]] of a [[computer file|file]] or [[directory (file systems)|directory]] in a computer [[file system]] or [[database]] * A proof of authenticity of a person (if a picture is timestamped it asserts the image is original) on sites such as [[4chan]]
==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time]]

revision.comment: Removed the reference to 'A timestamp is the time at which an event is recorded by a computer, not the time of the event itself.' - This is non-sensical and would mean that the only timestamp that could be created for a record is the current timestamp on a computer.

Some [[file archiver]]s and some [[comparison of version control software | version control software]], when they copy a file from some remote computer to the local computer, adjust the timestamps of the local file to show the date/time in the past when that file was created or modified on that remote computer, rather than the date/time when that file was copied to the local computer. == Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Wed 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]]) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC) * 1985-102 T 10:15 UTC ''(year 1985, day 102 = 12 April 1985)'' * 1985-W15-5 T 10:15 UTC ''(year 1985, week 15, day 5 = 12 April 1985)'' * 20180203073000 (02/03/2018 7:30:00) ==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}} These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values. ==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Time]]

revision.text: [[File:Transit_of_Venus_2012_(Rhodes).JPG|thumb|A photo of the [[transit of Venus]], with a timestamp shown in the bottom right corner.]] {{multiple image |perrow=1/1 |image1=Zeitstempel 01.jpg |image2=Uhrzeitstempel 05.jpg |footer=An actual time-[[rubber stamp|stamp]] from around 1960. }} A '''timestamp''' is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second. The term derives from [[rubber stamp]]s used in offices to stamp the current date, and sometimes time, in ink on paper documents, to record when the document was received. Common examples of this type of timestamp are a [[postmark]] on a letter or the "in" and "out" times on a [[time clock|time card]]. In modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, [[computer file]]s contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and [[digital camera]]s add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken. ==Digital timestamps== This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called [[timestamping (computing) | '''timestamping''']]. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping.{{cite book|author=Claudia Maria Bauzer Medeiros|title=ADVANCED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS -Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBnFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=19 September 2009|publisher=EOLSS Publications|isbn=978-1-905839-91-9|pages=59}} Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. Practically all computer file systems store one or more timestamps in the [[file system#Metadata | per-file metadata]]. In particular, most modern operating systems support the POSIX [[stat (system call)]], so each file has three timestamps associated with it: time of last access (atime: ls -lu), time of last modification (mtime: ls -l), and time of last status change (ctime: ls -lc). This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}} These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values. ==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Time]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 966244311 by [[Special:Contributions/2605:A000:D100:BE00:F93D:12B6:EFA9:1ADF|2605:A000:D100:BE00:F93D:12B6:EFA9:1ADF]] ([[User talk:2605:A000:D100:BE00:F93D:12B6:EFA9:1ADF|talk]]) I believe the original is correct. It's computers files in general (obviously not all of them, many rely on file system mtime), not some specific set of computer files. Just like the part about "digital cameras", not "the digital cameras". Thus I don't think the definite article should be used here.

In modern times usage of the term has expanded to refer to digital date and time information attached to digital data. For example, contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken. ==Digital timestamps== This data is usually presented in a consistent format, allowing for easy comparison of two different records and tracking progress over time; the practice of recording timestamps in a consistent manner along with the actual data is called [[timestamping (computing) | '''timestamping''']]. The sequential numbering of events is sometimes called timestamping.{{cite book|author=Claudia Maria Bauzer Medeiros|title=ADVANCED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS -Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBnFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59|date=19 September 2009|publisher=EOLSS Publications|isbn=978-1-905839-91-9|pages=59}} Timestamps are typically used for [[Data logging|logging events]] or in a [[sequence of events]] (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp. Practically all computer file systems store one or more timestamps in the [[file system#Metadata | per-file metadata]]. In particular, most modern operating systems support the POSIX [[stat (system call)]], so each file has three timestamps associated with it: time of last access (atime: ls -lu), time of last modification (mtime: ls -l), and time of last status change (ctime: ls -lc). Some [[file archiver]]s and some [[comparison of version control software | version control software]], when they copy a file from some remote computer to the local computer, adjust the timestamps of the local file to show the date/time in the past when that file was created or modified on that remote computer, rather than the date/time when that file was copied to the local computer. ==Standardization== [[ISO 8601]] standardizes the representation of dates and times.{{cite web |url=http://dotat.at/tmp/ISO_8601-2004_E.pdf |title=ISO 8601:2004(E) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2004-12-01 |publisher=[[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] |quote=3.5 Expansion … By mutual agreement of the partners in information interchange, it is permitted to expand the component identifying the calendar year, which is otherwise limited to four digits. This enables reference to dates and times in calendar years outside the range supported by complete representations, i.e. before the start of the year [0000] or after the end of the year [9999].}} These standard representations are often used to construct timestamp values. == Examples == Examples of timestamps: * Wed 01-01-2009 6:00 * 2005-10-30 T 10:45 [[UTC]] * 2007-11-09 T 11:20 [[UTC]] * Sat Jul 23 02:16:57 2005 * 2009-10-31T01:48:52Z (ISO 8601) * 1256953732 ([[Unix time]], equivalent to 2009-10-31T01:48:52Z) * (1969-07-21 T 02:56 UTC){{snd}} * 07:38, 11 December 2012 (UTC) * 1985-102 T 10:15 UTC ''(year 1985, day 102 = 12 April 1985)'' * 1985-W15-5 T 10:15 UTC ''(year 1985, week 15, day 5 = 12 April 1985)'' * 20180203073000 (02/03/2018 7:30:00) ==See also== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Timestamps}} * [[Bates numbering]] * [[Timestamping (computing)]] * [[Timestamp-based concurrency control]] * [[Trusted timestamping]] * [[Trusted timestamping#Decentralized timestamping on the blockchain|Decentralized Trusted Timestamping on the blockchain]] * [[Linked timestamping]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Time]]
